title: Alibaba’s Indian start-up deal
content:
Employees at the One97 Communications headquarters in Noida, Uttar Pradesh, India. Source: Supplied Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group is investing in an Indian mobile payments company, its latest move into the South Asian nation’s start-up boom. Alibaba and its financial services affiliate, Zhejiang Ant Small & Micro Financial Services Group (known as Ant Financial), are jointly investing in India’s One97 Communications, which runs PayTM, India’s dominant mobile-payments service.

Alibaba and Ant Financial wouldn’t disclose the value of the deal or how large a stake they have in One97. In February, Ant Financial said it was buying a 25 per cent stake in One97 for an undisclosed amount.

Sources said the investment gave Alibaba and Ant Financial a combined 40 per cent stake in One97, and that the companies had invested a total of about $US680 million ($970m) for the One97 stake.

Alibaba, which runs China’s largest e-commerce empire, has been searching for a foothold in India’s budding online retail market as it faces increased competition and slowing revenue growth at home. Last month, it invested $US200m in Snapdeal, one of India’s largest e-commerce companies.

One97 said it planned to use the funds to reach its goal of having 500 million Indians using its services. Close to 100 million Indians already used One97, the company said.
